text.title: Describe the Process of Bone Healing to Kids
text.head: Describe the Process of Bone Healing to Kids
text.p: When a child breaks a bone , they are often scared and have many questions about how it is going to fix itself . Explaining what is going on to the child can be quite difficult as the answers are often way beyond their comprehension . It is important to use diagrams and terminology they can understand . This article will provide strategies for explaining complex processes to children , along with a format to explain the bone healing process in a way a child can understand .
text.head: Steps
Meeting Them at Their Level

list.item: Ensure they know what a bone is . Although the child may have heard the term bone several times they may not be entirely sure what it is . Show the child pictures of a bone and explain where they can be found in the body and the role they play .

Use visuals . It is important to show the child pictures and labelled diagrams of each step in the bone healing processes . Providing visual aids will help to captivate the child 's interest by increasing their focus . Having visuals will also aid in the child 's comprehension .
Keep it simple . Try to use vocabulary they already know . Avoid using scientific terms but rather describe it using physical attributes or the function .

Use similes . There will be some new terms you cannot avoid using . When this happens use smilies to help the child understand . A smilie is the comparison of two different things in order to create a new meaning . The comparison is usually made using the words " like " or " as . "

Eliminate the details . Providing the child with every little detail about the bone healing process will only confuse them . Try to focus on the major components of the process and eliminate any that seem insignificant .

text.head: Explaining the Bone Healing Process

list.item:
Explain the hematoma formation as a pool of blood . Explain to the child that when the bone breaks it tears the blood vessels surrounding it . The blood coming from the blood vessels then pools around where the break happened . The torn blood vessels slowly stop releasing blood because they are clogged with cells . By saying the blood vessels are clogged you can avoid using the term clotting process .
If the child does not know what a blood vessel is explain it as a tube which blood flows through much like a garden hose with water flowing through it .

Explain what happens to the surrounding cells by comparing what happens to people when they do nâ€™t eat . Explain to the child that blood carries nutrients to cells . Tell the child nutrients are like food for our cells . When blood vessels tear during a break blood can no longer flow through them properly so nutrients cannot get to the bone cells around the break and they die . Just like how people ca n't live without food , the bone cells ca n't live without nutrients so they begin to die .

Compare the blood vessels growing into the hematoma as roots growing into the soil . A few days after the break , tiny blood vessels start to grow into the pool of blood . These small blood vessels grow off of the broken blood vessels much like how roots branch off a trunk into the soil . Inform the child that these small blood vessels connect the ends of the broken blood vessels back together . Make sure the child understands that this allows blood to flow normally again .

Explain phagocytic cells as special cells that eat dead cells . Do not use the proper name , phagocytic cells , as this could be confusing for the child . Refer to phagocytic cells as " special cells " that come and eat the dead cells to get rid of them . By calling them special cells the child will get the idea that they are different from other cells .

Express the bone formation process by the physical features or the function of the biological term .
Instead of using the proper terminology , fibroblasts and osteoblasts , refer to them as bone forming cells . Bone forming cells enter the area where the blood pool occurred and begin to remake the bone .
You can avoid using the term collagen fibers by explaining their physical properties . The broken bone ends are connected with bundles of long thread like structures made out of protein .
You can refer to fibrocartilaginous callus as a repair tissue . A temporary repair tissue is built between the broken bones .

Explain about spongy bone by focusing on its physical attributes . The repair tissue is turned into spongy bone . This spongy bone forms the inner layer of all bones and it looks a lot like a sponge . It takes about 2 months for the broken bone ends to be joined together . Show a picture of spongy bone to help the child understand .
Define remodeling to explain bone remodeling . The spongy bone is then remodeled meaning the old bone is replaced by new bone .
Compare compact bone to a shell . Lastly , a hard outer layer forms over the bone to provide protection and strength much like a shell .
